sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kent Eisenhuth & Kai Chang)
articles.description: In this article, we will explore how an accessibility-first approach can lead you down the path of creating a better visual design for charts. Throughout the article, you’ll learn to use the Web Content Accessibility Standards and how this approach leadd to an unexpected yet better outcome for everyone.
articles.title: An Accessibility-First Approach To Chart Visual Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In this [series of articles](/category/design-patterns/), we highlight design patterns and techniques to design better interfaces. You can find more examples in [“Smart Interface Design Patterns”](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/), a 7h-video course with 100s of hand-picked examples, curated by Vitaly.
articles.title: Designing A Better Pricing Page

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this tutorial, Zara Cooper explains how to use Strapi’s Internationalization feature to create content in multiple languages. You’ll also learn how to create a Hugo site that consumes localized content from Strapi.
articles.title: How To Build A Localized Website With Hugo And Strapi

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (John Scott Bowie)
articles.description: In this article, John Scott Bowie shares the story of 40 years of attempts to advance corporate UX maturity that — after numerous initiatives with marginal results — culminated in a breakthrough project that accelerated a company’s UX maturity from “Emergent” to “User-Driven” in less than a year.
articles.title: Accelerating UX Maturity With A Breakthrough Project

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s welcome the new month with some inspiring desktop wallpapers. Created by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for July 2022. Enjoy!
articles.title: Jump Into July (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we ask if Sass is still relevant in 2022 and if it adds any value modern CSS workflows. Vitaly talks to expert Stephanie Eckles to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 48 With Stephanie Eckles: Is Sass Still Relevant?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: Gatsby 4 came out in October 2021 with a lot of new features. It may seem as if Gatsby 4 didn’t cause a big stir among developers, but it brought several game-changing features. Let’s see what v4 brings to the table.
articles.title: Demystifying The New Gatsby Framework

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eric Bailey)
articles.description: Partially visually hidden link names may be good for people who use screen readers, but they can be problematic for those who rely on voice control software. Here’s a suggestion on how to solve this.
articles.title: Voice Control Usability Considerations For Partially Visually Hidden Link Names

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Anna Prenzel)
articles.description: In this article, we will enhance the Gantt Chart component with some interaction possibilities for editing the jobs. In doing so, we will continue to work with Vanilla JS and Web Components and look at some JavaScript libraries that can greatly simplify the effort of developing a fully functional Gantt Chart.
articles.title: How To Create A Vanilla JavaScript Gantt Chart: Adding Task Editing Features (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sergey Krasotin)
articles.description: Looking for ways to test your product faster? In this article, Sergey Krasotin uncovers common mistakes startup product designers make that lead to longer MVP testing times. To test your product within two weeks or even less, follow these simple practices proven by Sergey’s experience with over 100 startups and accelerators.
articles.title: How To Test Your MVP Within 2 Weeks (Or Less)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Do you feel stuck in your company? Do you believe you deserve a raise but it never happens? Do you think you might need to quit the job? Let’s figure it out. In this article, Vitaly looks at some things he wishes he’d known earlier in his career.
articles.title: Things I Wish I’d Known Earlier In My Career

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kirill Myshkin)
articles.description: In JavaScript, it’s natural to reach for timers when something is to happen on time. But when something is to happen at the exact moment because other things depend on it, you quickly learn timers are more of a problem than a solution. They are never on time, really. Web Animations API could eliminate the need for timers in certain cases while being precise.
articles.title: Precise Timing With Web Animations API

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andrii Zhdan)
articles.description: In this article, Andrii shares his approach to managing tables in Figma in an easier, more streamlined way when there is a need to support different screen resolutions, change the order of columns, and use real-life content.
articles.title: How To Easily Build And Support Tables In Figma

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: All the data in the world won’t do anyone any good if we can’t make sense of it. Or better yet, make it sing. Here are some stunning examples of data visualization in the wild, and some pointers on how to start making your own.
articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Delightful Data Visualization Examples

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cristian Díaz)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll see how to make our sites friendly for Windows High Contrast Mode by using a good set of practices, including the media query `forced-colors` and its toolset.
articles.title: The Guide To Windows High Contrast Mode

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: Do you need search for your site, but haven’t found the time to add it? Within 15 minutes, Leonardo Losoviz explains how you can add a super powerful search that also looks super good. In this article, you’ll learn how to go from 0 to 100 with search.
articles.title: Adding Search To Your Site In 15 Minutes

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eva Rio)
articles.description: In this article, Eva gives an overview of what embedded systems are and how they impact our lives. She presents three main learnings gained across her quest for creating better-embedded systems to enable the world as we know it.
articles.title: How To Apply UX Principles To Embedded Systems: Learnings From The Field

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: [DevFest for Ukraine](https://devfest.gdg.org.ua/) is a charitable online conference that will bring together 20 industry-leading tech speakers in support of Ukraine. June 14–15.
articles.title: DevFest For Ukraine, A Charity Conference On The Future Of Tech 🇺🇦

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Thomas Bohm)
articles.description: In this article, Thomas Bohm explains ways to test typefaces and other typographic issues. Though this article is slightly high-end and academic, fear not. The content will be interesting, especially for committed typeface designers and typographers. If you like complex issues and problems, this is for you.
articles.title: Measuring The Performance Of Typefaces For Users (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Joseph)
articles.description: This article explores the evolution and the future of frontend tooling, presenting a new set of tools featuring a change in paradigm, platform, or both.
articles.title: The Future Of Frontend Build Tools

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When working with dictionaries in Python, a KeyError gets raised when you try to access an item that doesn't exist in a Python dictionary. Here's a Python dictionary called student: student = {   "name": "John",   "course": "Python", } In the dictionary above, you can access the
articles.title: keyerror in Python – How to Fix Dictionary Error

articles.author: Joel Olawanle
articles.description: Reversing strings in JavaScript is something you'll need to do often on your web development journey. You might need to reverse a string during interviews, when solving algorithms, or when doing data manipulation.
